title: How to Get Wrinkles Out of Polyester

steps.title: Check the care instructions on the item’s tag.
steps.content: Check the care instructions on the item’s tag. The suggested wash cycle and water temperature may vary depending on if the item is pure polyester or if it’s a blend. Delicate fabrics, such as a polyester and silk blend, may require a delicate wash cycle with cool or warm water. [1] X Research source If you’re unsure, wash the item with cold or warm water on the permanent press cycle. [2] X Expert Source Kamel Almani Laundry & Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 9 April 2021. Never use hot water to wash a polyester item as it can damage the fabric. [3] X Research source The care tag will also indicate if it’s okay to iron or dry the item, which you might want to know if washing and drying does not remove the wrinkles.

steps.title: Add a gentle detergent and fabric softener to your washing machine.
steps.content: Add a gentle detergent and fabric softener to your washing machine. A gentle detergent is less likely to damage the item, especially if it’s a delicate fabric blend. Add a gentle fabric softener to the washing machine as well. This will help to reduce the static after you dry the item. Polyester is known for its tendency to develop lots of static, so using fabric softener is highly recommended.

steps.title: Start the wash and remove the item right after the cycle ends.
steps.content: Start the wash and remove the item right after the cycle ends. Press the start button on the washing machine after you add the detergent and fabric softener. Listen for the cycle to finish and transfer the wet polyester from the washer to the dryer right away. Otherwise, the polyester item may develop new wrinkles.

steps.title: Dry the item
steps.content: Dry the item on the permanent press cycle for 15 to 20 minutes. Toss in a dryer sheet with the item to help reduce static, if desired. Then, set the heat to low and turn the dial to 20 minutes max. This should be enough heat and time to get the item dry. You can dry the item for longer if needed, but make sure to check it every 5 minutes after it's been in for 20 minutes. [4] X Expert Source Kamel Almani Laundry & Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 9 April 2021. [5] X Research source If your dryer does not have a permanent press cycle, then you can just select the lowest heat setting.

steps.title: Hang the item up immediately after it’s dry to prevent new wrinkles.
steps.content: Hang the item up immediately after it’s dry to prevent new wrinkles. Leaving the item sitting in the dryer may result in new wrinkles and possibly even permanent wrinkles. Take the item out of the dryer as soon as it’s dry and place it on a hanger to cool. [7] X Expert Source Kamel Almani Laundry & Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 9 April 2021. Leave the item alone for at least 5 minutes or as long as it takes for the fabric to cool down. [8] X Research source Once the fabric feels cool to the touch, you can safely wear or fold the item without wrinkling it.

steps.title: Turn on an iron to the lowest setting.
steps.content: Turn on an iron to the lowest setting. Polyester fabric cannot withstand high temperatures, so don’t crank the heat on your iron up to the max. Set it to low or turn it to the synthetic or polyester setting if your iron has one. [9] X Research source Check your iron’s instruction manual if you are unsure about what setting might be best for a polyester item.

steps.title: Spray the item with plain water to moisten the fabric.
steps.content: Spray the item with plain water to moisten the fabric. Fill a clean spray bottle with plain water and then spritz the polyester item all over to make it damp. If you don’t have a spray bottle, hold the item under running water and then wring out the excess. [10] X Research source Make sure that the item is not dripping wet when you iron it. If needed, hang it up and allow it to dry a little before ironing it.

steps.title: Turn the item inside out and spread it on an ironing board.
steps.content: Turn the item inside out and spread it on an ironing board. Stretch it gently with your hands to ensure that it is laying flat. [11] X Research source Smooth out the wrinkles in the item with your hand so that it is lying as flat as possible. [12] X Research source If you don’t have an ironing board, fold a towel in half and place it on a table, countertop, or bed. Then, place the polyester item on top of the towel. Turning the item inside out will help to prevent visible damage to the item if it gets too hot.

steps.title: Cover the item with a thin towel or T-shirt.
steps.content: Cover the item with a thin towel or T-shirt. Ensure that the towel or T-shirt is clean and dry. Smooth it out over the polyester item so that it lays flat. This will help to protect the item from becoming damaged by the heat of the iron. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Iron the fabric through the towel or shirt on low heat.
steps.content: Iron the fabric through the towel or shirt on low heat. Press the heated iron down on the towel or T-shirt and iron over the fabric to smooth it out. Continue to move the iron back and forth across the fabric until you have covered all of it 2-3 times. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Hang the item or leave it on the ironing board to dry it flat for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Hang the item or leave it on the ironing board to dry it flat for 5 minutes. Don’t try to fold or wear the item right away or it could develop new wrinkles. Instead, place the item on a hanger or leave it on the ironing board to cool. Then, don’t touch the item until it is completely cool. Check to ensure that the fabric feels cool before you fold or wear it. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Fill the iron’s reservoir with water and turn it on the steam setting.
steps.content: Fill the iron’s reservoir with water and turn it on the steam setting. Check the manufacturer’s instructions to determine how much water to add to the reservoir and to determine how long it will take to warm up. In most cases, 10-15 minutes should be plenty of time for the iron to get hot and start releasing steam. [16] X Research source You can also use a handheld steamer if you have one. Follow the manufacturer’s instructions for how much water to add to the reservoir and how long to let it heat up.

steps.title: Turn the polyester item inside out and place it on an ironing board.
steps.content: Turn the polyester item inside out and place it on an ironing board. While the iron is warming up, prepare your fabric on the ironing board. Turn it inside out so that you will be less likely to damage the fabric. Then, smooth it out on the ironing board as best you can. [17] X Research source If you don’t have an ironing board, fold a towel in half and place it on a table, countertop, or bed. Then, place the polyester item on top of it. Make sure to avoid using a colorful towel if the item is light or a pastel color. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Move the iron up and down while hovering it above the item.
steps.content: Move the iron up and down while hovering it above the item. Once the iron is releasing steam, pick it up and position it so that it is about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm) above the polyester item. Move it up and down over each of the wrinkled areas to smooth them out. Tug the edges of the item gently as you do this to help release the wrinkles. [19] X Research source Be very careful not to steam your skin! The steam is very hot and it can easily burn you.

steps.title: Hang the item or leave it on the ironing board to cool for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Hang the item or leave it on the ironing board to cool for 5 minutes. After you finish steaming each of the wrinkled sections of the item, transfer it to a hanger or leave it lying flat on the ironing board. Let the polyester item cool for 5 minutes. Don’t try to wear or fold the item until it is completely cool or it may develop new wrinkles. [20] X Research source Touch the fabric after 5 minutes to see if it is cool. If it is, you can wear the item or fold it and put it away.
